134.text:

158.text:

162.text:

Now let's discuss seating, which is absolutely
crucial. Where the student sits depends on

950.text:
many factors. For example, it depends on the
classroom seating arrangement, whether it

954.text:

the student with hearing loss should sit where

961.text:

965.text:

980.text:

986.text:
privilege. My English teacher, Dr. Redfern,
will tell us about seating for students with

997.text:
For row seating, the ideal place to seat the
student with hearing loss is in the front.

1003.text:
Being in the front allows the student to better
hear and see the teacher.

1007.text:
In the front row, the student can sit somewhat
to the right, somewhat to the left, or in

1013.text:
the center. Front center may not be the best;
it depends on the student. Sitting to the

1018.text:
right or left allows the student to observe
other students in the class.

1031.text:
Also, if the student has a better ear, meaning
the student can hear better with one ear than

1037.text:
the other, then the student should be seated
with the better ear toward the teacher and

1041.text:
the entire class, which may be to the right
or the left.

1045.text:
The student should be allowed to rotate in
the seat when necessary in order to see other

1058.text:
For circle seating, the student with hearing
loss should sit either to the right or the

1062.text:
left side of the teacher, sideways, at an
angle, so that he or she can have visual and

1068.text:
auditory access to the teacher and to the
other students. This way, the student doesn't

1073.text:
have to turn his or her body so much to see
the teacher. According to Mary Jane Johnson,

1078.text:
the student with hearing loss should not sit
right next the teacher and definitely not

1084.text:
directly across from the teacher; instead,
maybe two or three seats away from the teacher.

1096.text:
Regardless of these rules, Ms. Johnson and
other experts say that teachers should listen

1100.text:
to the student with hearing loss and let him
or her choose a seat. Only the student can

1106.text:
assess from which seat he or she has the best
access. Also, the student should be given

1111.text:
the option of trying different seats to see
which one suits him or her best. Again, this

1116.text: is a medical necessity, not a privilege.

1126.text:
The student with hearing loss should also
be seated as far away from any noise as possible,

1131.text:
especially if the noise cannot be removed.
Students who habitually make noise, like clicking

1136.text:
pens or fidgeting, should be seated away from
the student with hearing loss.

1141.text:
Another factor to take into account is lighting.
The student should sit where the lighting

1145.text:
in the classroom gives him or her good visibility
of the teacher and the other students.

1150.text:
Some seating selections are known not to work
for students with hearing loss. Examples with

1155.text:
row seating include: sitting in the center
or the back during lectures, sitting in the

1161.text:
front center while a large group discussion
is going on, or seating in the front watching

1166.text:
a video with the speakers in the back of the
room.

1170.text:
To summarize, a student with hearing loss
will require preferential seating to allow

1175.text:
him or her to see and learn as much as possible.
Seating accommodation is not a luxury; it

1181.text:
is a necessity for the student with hearing
loss.

1212.text:

discussants increases, the student with hearing

1222.text:
loss will get lost and isolated, especially

Mr. Halback, will now describe some of the

It is difficult for a student with hearing
loss to hear and understand teachers, but

1247.text:
it is much, much more difficult for the student

1252.text:
Unlike most teachers, students are not as
comfortable with the material and often speak

1256.text:

1265.text:
thinking about teaching their peers. Therefore,
the teacher should always assume that the

1270.text:
student with hearing loss does not hear other
students during classroom discussions and

To help the student with hearing loss, the

1291.text:
answers, and comments. This is especially

1296.text:
or are sitting in the back or away from the

1301.text:
The teacher should also expand, paraphrase,
and summarize students' comments, not just

The teacher should encourage students to speak

During classroom discussions, the teacher

the student with hearing loss to know who

During long group discussions, the student

the student with hearing loss to a different

1368.text:
better hear and see other students. Another

Remember that classroom discussions often

loss. The teacher should provide opportunities

and to interact with other students in the

The student with hearing loss will most likely
be lost and excluded when multiple students

are talking especially at the same time, when

topics change rapidly. The ideal solution

should also repeat and paraphrase what was

To summarize, classroom discussions are very

Please make sure that the student with hearing

1440.text:
Communicating with a student with hearing
loss requires effort and patience. To begin

1445.text:
with, the student does not hear well, even
with hearing aids or cochlear implants. Hearing

1449.text:
loss is not like shortsightedness, for example.
There is no such thing as 20/20 hearing with

1455.text:
any hearing aid or other device. Under the
best circumstances, the student with hearing

1459.text:
loss will still miss a good percentage of
what is said. In addition, most students with

1464.text:
hearing loss also have speech impairments,
accents, or other issues. The student with

1469.text:
hearing loss probably underwent years of speech
therapy just to be able to speak. I certainly

1474.text:
did. As a result, communicating with a student
with hearing loss can be frustrating. Speaking

1480.text:
from personal experience, I can say that a
student with hearing loss is often misunderstood

1485.text:
as rude or even dumb, just because they can't
hear and can't speak as well as students with

1491.text:
normal hearing. Now, my history teacher, Mr.
Halback, will share some tips for communicating

1496.text: with a student with hearing loss.

1505.text:
First of all, try to avoid conversations with
the student with hearing loss in noisy places,

1510.text:
such as hallways, lunch rooms, cafeterias,
gymnasiums, activity rooms, playgrounds.

1517.text:
Second, before you start speaking with the
student with hearing loss, in the classroom

1522.text:
or individually, you need to get the student's
attention first. For example, call the student

1527.text:
by name, and make sure that the student recognized
that you called him or her. Try to get the

1533.text:
student's visual and auditory attention before
speaking to the student. Make sure the student

1538.text:
is looking at you and knows that you are speaking
to him or her. With a young student, you may

1544.text:
need to tap the student on the shoulder to
get his or her attention.

1552.text:
When a student with hearing loss comes to
talk to me, I turn my entire body, not just

1557.text:
my head, to face him or her. Turning my entire
body shows that I am available and focused,

1563.text: and it also allows me to focus better.

1566.text:
During the conversation, face the student
and maintain eye contact. With young students,

1571.text:
the teacher will need to get down at the student's
level while talking to the student.

1579.text:
Students with hearing loss rely more heavily
on visual cues to decipher what is being said.

1585.text:
The teacher and the student with hearing loss
can agree on certain nonverbal signals to

1590.text:
communicate without disturbing the class or
perhaps calling attention to the student.

1595.text:
For example, the student can put a certain
notebook out, or perhaps a color coded card,

1600.text:
or object to indicate that the student did
not hear, did not understand, or perhaps is

1605.text:
lost. In addition, the teacher should use
visual teaching techniques and visual aids

1617.text:
It is not a good idea for the teacher to suddenly
call on the student with hearing loss to answer

1620.text:
a question or to comment on another student's
answer, unless the student with hearing loss

1625.text:
is raising his or her hand. The student with
hearing loss may be lost, and putting him

1630.text:
or her on the spot will cause embarrassment
and awkwardness. Additionally, don't keep

1636.text:
saying to the student, "can you hear me?"
"do you understand?" especially in front of

1641.text:
the class or other students. It embarrasses
the student.

1652.text:
The student with hearing loss should be given
opportunities to speak and participate in

1656.text:
class. The student should be given some leadership
opportunities in the classroom, for example,

1661.text:
by assigning the student to be a team leader
in classroom exercises.

1665.text:
Don't expect or demand the student with hearing
loss to speak as well as students with normal

1669.text:
hearing. Please be patient, respectful, understanding,
and encouraging; the student is probably doing

1676.text:
his best or her best to speak the way he or
she is.

1680.text:
To summarize, when communicating with a student
with hearing loss, whether in the classroom

1686.text:
or otherwise, please ensure that he or she
is hearing you before and during the conversation.

Now we will turn to testing considerations.
Certain testing circumstances put the student

1708.text:
with hearing loss at a significant disadvantage
purely for his or her hearing loss. So, when

1714.text:
it comes to tests, students with hearing loss
also require certain accommodations. For example,

1719.text:
if the hearing loss is severe enough, the
student with hearing loss may be able to receive

1724.text:
extended test time, if they can show medical
proof of the severity of the hearing loss.

1730.text:
According to the SRI study I mentioned in
the beginning, about 60% of students with

1735.text:
hearing loss receive extended test time. Some
students with normal hearing may feel that

1740.text:
giving accommodations to students with hearing
loss is unfair. However, the student with

1745.text:
hearing loss is constantly trying to figure
out what is being said in class in addition

1750.text:
to trying to comprehend it while students
with normal hearing use the time to readily

1756.text:
comprehend the material. So, again, accommodations
are needed due to medical necessity, not privilege.

1762.text:
My economics teacher, Mr. Lepler, will now

1774.text:
Most importantly, test reminders and test
instructions must be provided in writing,

1781.text: ideally on the board and on paper.

1784.text:
Test instructions and test questions must
be clear. Using tricky language can put the

1789.text: student with hearing loss at a disadvantage.

1793.text:
Noise is detrimental to students with hearing
loss, especially during tests. The classroom

1800.text:
must be kept quiet. You may have to give the
student the option of taking the test elsewhere.

1813.text:
The student with hearing loss should not be
quizzed on anything that was covered verbally

1823.text:
The student with hearing loss should also
not be quizzed on new material immediately

1827.text:
after it was covered. Remember that the student
with hearing loss probably did not hear everything

1834.text:
that was said in class, and it would be grossly
unfair to test him or her on the new material.

1840.text:
Instead, give the student the opportunity
to study at home and be told when the test

1846.text:
is well ahead of time. Because of their inability
to hear, students with hearing loss generally

1853.text:
take more time to study, because they don't
learn as much in class as students with normal

1865.text:
The student with hearing loss should not be
quizzed on material that was covered only

1870.text:
in videos, audio recordings, class discussions,
or student oral presentations without both

1877.text:
written notes and the chance to study and
digest the material at home.

1888.text:
Additionally, the student with hearing loss
may be confused if test instructions are changed

1894.text:
the last minute, for example adding a new
section to the test only the day before

1901.text:
The student with hearing loss should not be
tested orally. If they have to be tested orally,

1907.text:
for example with vocabulary, they should be
given oral practice examples and oral practice

1916.text:
To summarize, test instructions and questions
should be clear and written, and tests should

1924.text:
assess material for which written notes were
provided before the test.

1944.text:
One of the annoying issues with hearing aids
is that they magnify almost everything indiscriminately

1949.text:
including noise; if the noise is loud enough,
the student will hear nothing but the noise.

2002.text:

2021.text:
